newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY BANK BAIL-OUT PROBE YIELDS RESULTS - GOVT.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY BANK BAIL-OUT PROBE YIELDS RESULTS - GOVT.

text.p: The Hungarian government said on Thursday the Finance Ministry will continue investigations into irregularities of a bank consolidation programme started by the previous administration.
"Further investigation is needed to determine personal responsibilities," government spokesman Elemer Kiss told a news conference following the regular cabinet meeting.

Hungary's previous conservative government implemented three consecutive bank consolidation programmes between 1991 and 1994, raising the capital adequacy ratios of banks to eight percent in debt-for-equity swaps.
Some 315 billion forints of public money has been spent on the programmes, of which only 12 billion was injected by the current administration.
The investigation was conducted by a nine-strong team of the Government Supervisory Office.
Kiss cited one irregularity involving the now-liquidated that Ybl Bank, which received 2.7 billion forints to cover its debts.
He also said irregularities were found at banks still in operation, but said the government had decided not to disclose any more details while investigations were continuing.
Kiss said the Finance Ministry would forward the cases to the public prosecutor should the inquiry uncover any illegal dealings.
He added that all investigations will be completed by March 31.
